channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: World Briefing: Serbia: Visit by Albania’s Premier Fails to Reduce Tensions
item.description: The prime ministers of Serbia and Albania pledged Monday to put their differences aside and focus on their mutual desire to join the European Union — but the good feelings did not last until the end of their joint news conference.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Air Quality App Forced to Stop Providing Data From U.S. Embassy
item.description: One of China’s most popular air quality monitoring apps has stopped providing data from a device that sits atop the roof of the United States Embassy in Beijing.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW JACOBS
item.media:description: Pedestrians in Beijing wearing masks against air pollution.

item.title: World Briefing: South Sudan: Cease-Fire Ends After 48 Hours
item.description: Forty-eight hours after the latest cease-fire deal in South Sudan, a battle broke out on Monday between government troops and rebel fighters in which 29 combatants died, said a military spokesman.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: South Africa: Pistorius Appeal Hearing Set for Dec. 9
item.description: Prosecutors, who called the sentence “shockingly light," have said Mr. Pistorius should have been found guilty of murder for killing his girlfriend, Reeva Steenkamp, in 2013.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q. and A.: Dennis M. Gormley on China’s Military Capabilities
item.description: Dennis M. Gormley, a senior lecturer in military affairs at the University of Pittsburgh’s Graduate School of Public and International Affairs, discusses China’s air defenses.
item.dc:creator: By BREE FENG

item.title: Malala Yousafzai, Nobel Laureate, Is Assailed by Schools Group in Pakistan
item.description: A network of private schools on Monday called for a day of protest against Ms. Yousafzai, 17, and her memoir about being shot by a Taliban gunman after pressing for girls’ rights and education.
item.dc:creator: By SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: World Briefing: Thailand: Police to Send Migrants Back Out to Sea in Boats
item.description: More than 200 migrants from Myanmar who are being held in southern Thailand will be pushed back out to sea, the police said Monday.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: India: Court Allows Women to Work as Makeup Artists in Film Industry
item.description: India’s Supreme Court on Monday ordered the lifting of a ban on women working as makeup artists in the movie industry, ending a discriminatory practice that has endured for decades.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: For Guccifer, Hacking Was Easy. Prison Is Hard.
item.description: Calling himself Guccifer, Marcel-Lehel Lazar rampaged through the email accounts of rich and powerful Americans and others, showing the ease of going rogue on the Internet.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS
item.media:credit: Cristian Movila for The New York Times
item.media:description: Marcel-Lehel Lazar, a.k.a Guccifer, tormented various celebrities with no special skills beyond what he had picked up on the web.

item.title: T Magazine: The Knowledge, London’s Legendary Taxi-Driver Test, Puts Up a Fight in the Age of GPS
item.description: Memorizing the city’s 25,000 streets might be the most difficult test in the world. As technology imperils this tradition, is there an argument for learning as an end in itself?
item.dc:creator: By JODY ROSEN

item.title: China Builds Financial Ties to Neighbors
item.description: Trade agreements with neighboring nations underscore China’s rising economic clout, as it competes more aggressively for deals and investment dollars.
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER and ALEXANDRA STEVENSON
item.media:description: As the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum opened, China said it would allow investors in Shanghai and Hong Kong, seen here, to trade on each other’s markets.

item.title: Palestinians Are Suspected as 2 Israelis Die in Knife Attacks
item.description: A civilian was killed in the West Bank and a soldier was fatally wounded near a crowded train station in Tel Aviv.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN
item.media:description: Paramedics treated an Israeli soldier who was stabbed at a train station in Tel Aviv on Monday.

item.title: Russian News Agency Expands Global Reach
item.description: The major expansion of Russia’s state news agency into the West, including capitals like Washington and Berlin, is intended to counter what Russia describes as Western propaganda.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW ROTH

item.title: World Briefing: South Africa: Court Order Muzzles Outspoken Puppet
item.description: The ventriloquist, Conrad Koch, said Monday that he would challenge a court order intended to silence his puppet.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Halmaj Journal: Work-for-Welfare Gains a Foothold in Hungary
item.description: Under the right-wing rule of Prime Minister Viktor Orban, the unemployed in Halmaj — a poor, rural village of 1,800 — must work to get more public assistance.
item.dc:creator: By RICK LYMAN
item.media:credit: Akos Stiller for The New York Times
item.media:description: Thousands of Hungarians have taken jobs in so-called communal work programs to qualify for more in public assistance.

item.title: Open Source: Sierra Leone Defends Jailing Critic of Ebola Response
item.description: The attorney general in Sierra Leone said a prominent radio journalist had undermined the government’s effort to stop the disease’s spread.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: At War Blog: Marines Remember Falluja, 10 Years Later
item.description: On Nov. 6, 2004, NATO forces launched an assault on Falluja, a city north of Baghdad that had become a magnet for Sunni insurgent forces, and the resulting battle was one of the bloodiest for American forces since Vietnam. Thomas James Brennan fought there with the 1st Battalion, 8th Marine Regiment; he and other veterans of the assault say that their memories of Fallujah will never leave them.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS JAMES BRENNAN
item.media:description: Marines of the First Battalion, Eighth Marine Regiment responded to enemy contact in Falluja, Iraq, in November 2004.

item.title: Sarkozy Tries Quick Comeback, but France May Not Go Along
item.description: The former French president is campaigning for the leadership of his center-right party, but there is little doubt that his sights are on a return to the Élysée Palace.
item.dc:creator: By SUZANNE DALEY
item.media:description: Nicolas Sarkozy at a meeting in Paris last week. Mr. Sarkozy is seeking the presidency of his center-right party, the Union for a Popular Movement.

item.title: Explaining Boko Haram, Nigeria’s Islamist Insurgency
item.description: Boko Haram is largely known for its kidnapping of schoolgirls in Nigeria, but it is suspected of having committed atrocities before and after those abductions.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Obama’s Focus in China Is on Leader, Not Public
item.description: President Obama is nurturing his one-on-one relationship with China’s president, after his past efforts to engage with the Chinese public were stymied.
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER
item.media:description: From left, Hassanal Bolkiah, the sultan of Brunei; President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia; President Xi Jinping of China and his wife, Peng Liyuan; and President Obama arriving for a ceremonial reception on Monday at the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation summit meeting in Beijing.

item.title: Militant Group in Egypt Vows Loyalty to ISIS
item.description: The affiliation could pull the organization, Ansar Beit al-Maqdis, away from its focus on attacking Egyptian military and security forces and toward the Islamic State’s mass killings of civilians.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
item.media:description: A military vehicle moved last week amid homes destroyed by Egyptian security forces in Rafah, an area of Sinai that is a stronghold of Ansar Beit al-Maqdis.

item.title: Bomb at School in Nigeria Kills Nearly 50 Boys
item.description: Nearly 50 boys at a boarding school were killed in the bombing, and suspicion focused on the Boko Haram militant group, which has carried out similar attacks.
item.dc:creator: By ADAM NOSSITER
item.media:description: Hospital workers treated survivors of a suicide bombing at a high school in Potiskum, Nigeria, on Monday.

item.title: U.N. to Investigate Strikes on Its Facilities in Gaza
item.description: A panel will investigate the attacks on more than 100 United Nations facilities and the death of 11 staff members during the Gaza conflict during the summer.
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: World Briefing: U.S. Imposes Sanctions on Yemen’s Ex-President and 2 Rebel Leaders
item.description: The Obama administration accused former President Ali Abdullah Saleh of undermining “stability” in Yemen by backing a rebel group that recently took control of its capital.
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM

item.title: World Briefing: Italian Appeals Court Overturns Guilty Verdicts in Earthquake Trial
item.description: Seven earthquake experts had been convicted of manslaughter for failing to adequately warn residents before a 2009 quake that killed more than 300 people.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETTA POVOLEDO
